• Children will be divided into ‚Äúbubbles‚Äù of no more than 15 children. Each bubble will be kept separate from other bubbles at all times.

  • Children will be encouraged to wash their hands regularly throughout the day, and antibacterial gel will be available in every classroom.

  • Rooms will be kept well ventilated using natural ventilation by keeping the windows open as much as possible.

  • Door handles, taps and toilet flush handles will be wiped clean numerous times during the day. All doors will be propped open so no one needs to touch the handles.

  • Tissues will be available in all classrooms. Children will be taught to cough or sneeze into their elbow and to use bins for tissue waste (‚Äòcatch it, bin it, kill it‚Äô).

  • Dustbins will be kept covered at all times.

  • Toilets will be cleaned numerous times during the day.

  • Surfaces and resources will be wiped down frequently throughout the day.

  • All areas will be thoroughly cleaned every afternoon.

  • A Medical Room has been designated. Any child who is unwell will be isolated (under adult supervision) in the Medical Room and parents will be asked to collect their child immediately.

September

Indigenous Literacy Day




Indigenous Literacy Day is a national celebration of Indigenous culture, stories, language and literacy. Through activities on the day, we focus our attention on the disadvantages experienced in remote communities and encourage the rest of Australia to raise funds and advocate for more equal access to literacy resources for remote communities.




Further learning:




  • Indigenous Literacy Foundation







13 September 2007

Anniversary of the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP)




The United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP) was adopted by the General Assembly on Thursday, 13 September 2007, by a majority of 144 states in favour, 4 votes against (Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the United States) and 11 abstentions (Azerbaijan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Burundi, Colombia, Georgia, Kenya, Nigeria, Russian Federation, Samoa and Ukraine).




Further learning:




  • The United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples


  • The United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples video






25 September 2000

Cathy Freeman wins Olympic Gold medal




Kuku Yalanji woman Cathy Freeman won the gold medal in the 400m at the Sydney Olympic Games. She was the first Australian woman to win an individual track event in 36 years and became the first Aboriginal person to be an Athletics Olympic Champion.




Further learning:




  • Born to Run - Cathy Freeman
  • Freeman

Though not officially affiliated with the work of the Ferguson Commission, the Ferguson Commission’s call to understand the impacts of racial inequities in St. Louis influenced the creation of this effort. The increased focus on racial equity across St. Louis, as well as local partners engaged (currently and historically), in both race and gender equity work offers ample opportunities for cross-effort learning and collaboration.





This is work is also informed and connected to other efforts in St. Louis addressing topics that are related to who can be successful in entrepreneurship, including education, criminal justice, public health and banking. We are informed by the following regional efforts and reports:




  • Alive and Well
  • MCU Break the Pipeline
  • Ferguson Commission Report/Forward Through Ferguson
  • Generate Health St. Louis
  • Ready by 21
  • STEM STL
  • Thread STL
  • Health Equity Works FKA For the Sake of All



For more information about how these overlapping efforts are related, please contact us.

Physical Science is excellent preparation for higher level bio, chem, and physics classes! This class allows students to enjoy learning about atomic structure, the periodic table, chemical bonds, reactions and energy, motion, forces, energy, waves and sound, light, electricity and magnetism, Earth’s structure, weathering, and atmosphere. Students will see they can observe a phenomenon, ask questions, and test those questions during lab periods of interaction and hands-on experimentation! Every year students show great growth as they develop critical thinking, science vocabulary, and formal writing skills working on their lab reports! With about one hour of interactive lecture and one hour of lab experiments each week, students are always engaged in building these challenging science skills! Because of the calculations and formulas that students will encounter in this text, It is highly recommended that students who take this course be at an algebra level in math.



Instructor: Christa Miller, 1.5 Credits; $12.00/wk






Text Required:





  • Apologia Exploring Creation with Physical Science Textbook; 3rd Edition

  • Apologia Exploring Creation with Physical Science, 3rd Edition, Test Pages


  • Note: Must have 3rd Edition; can price check at Christain Book Distributors.com, Rainbow Resources, etc.





Lab Fee:




  • $20 Paid directly to the teacher at the beginning of the school year

This can be both the most fun and the most tedious part of a show. On the one hand, it’s not too strenuous and you get to meet lots of amazing performers, on the other, you will be in a room doing the same thing for hours on end. For a smaller show you might be able to get all auditions done in a couple of days, but for a Playhouse scale show you’ll probably be looking at a solid 5 days of auditions (you can of course choose to open less audition slots or do group auditions to lower this time but you will be limiting the number of people you see – and as you never know who might be your next leading player, I’d always recommend making room for everyone to audition if they would like to).





Another way of auditioning that we’re just starting to explore due to the pandemic is doing the first round of auditions via video submission. This makes this round a lot easier for so many reasons, including:




  • you don’t have to book rooms to hold auditions in;
  • no worries about people showing up late and that shifting the timetable for the day;
  • auditionees are often less nervous and have the chance to rerecord until they’re happy with their submission;
  • you can rewatch the auditions multiple times, which is super helpful if you’re making the callback decision a while after you saw the first audition, as it means you can see everyone fresh and not just make decisions from notes;
  • everyone on the audition panel can watch the videos in their own time, around their busy schedules, and then you can find a couple of hours to meet up and make call back decisions, rather than needing a whole week when you’re all free at the same times.



Whilst this way of auditioning was set up because of safety regulations, I think it’s definitely something to consider going forward for all these reasons.





That said, when it comes to callbacks (which you should really do for every role if possible) I’d recommend doing them in person, if regulations allow it. In the first round of auditions you’re looking to see if the auditionee a) has the necessary talent for the show in whatever disciplines you need, and b) has the potential to fit at least one of the characters. However, as they probably won't have shown you a character extract in the first round of auditions (it’s customary to allow the auditionee to pick their own monologue/song in the first round), the callbacks are a chance to see how they fit into the character roles you’re considering them for.





It’s also a good idea to try giving them some direction in the callback. Whether they need it or not, give them adjustment to make second time around so you can see how they respond to direction. If they don’t respond to the way you direct them, they might be tricky to work with them later on (not always – it’s always tricky to decipher everything from a callback, but it’s useful to get an idea of it!). If the auditionee is very good and I can’t think of an adjustment to give them, I like to give them a ‘try this’ scenario in which I ask them to do something really unexpected e.g play this sweet romantic monologue as though you’re a psychopath – it won’t help me see if they’re a better fit for the character, but it’ll show me how comfortable a performer they are, what range they have, and how they respond to direction.





For more info on auditions check out these other pages:




  • Welfare for Oxford drama
  • Audition Walk Through
  • Organising auditions



The welfare guidelines should definitely be read, as they state all the protocols you should be following throughout the entire process (including things like audition etiquette etc).





One last pointer I’d give is to always go into auditions with an open mind. Be open to your idea of a character being pushed in a new direction by the way an auditionee presents them, be open to casting against your original thoughts, and be willing to take a chance on someone if your gut is telling them you should cast them.

The Veterans in the Ring program is for qualified veterans to train at Gleason’s Gym, Inc. at no charge.




Gleason’s is the oldest and largest boxing gym in The United States. We have trained 134 World Champions, 2 Olympic Gold medal winners and hundreds of other champions.




In appreciation for the veterans service, Gleason’s opens it’s doors to the men and women that are referred to us by the VA Adaptive Sports Program.




Medical clearance is required to participate in the VA Adaptive Sports Programs. To obtain medical clearance, contact Jonathan Glasberg, Department of Veteran Affairs, VA Hospital NYC 212 686-7500 X 7779 or he will arrange for a VA physician to write a note and have it placed in your electronic medical record.








The note title must be:




“Adaptive Sports Medical Clearance Note”.




Medical clearance with this note lasts for 1 full year.




Once this form is presented to Gleason’s Gym, the veteran will be given free complementary membership, along with two training sessions weekly.

Yes, many of my members are beginners.




We are open seven days a week.





  • Monday through Friday, from 5:00 am until 10:00 pm.



  • On Saturday and Sunday from 8:00 am until 6:00 pm.



  • The monthly fee is $110. There is no sign up fee nor contract.






We have 92 trainers and their fee starts at $50 per hour. They will bargain with you.




I suggest that you visit the gym at the time of day that you intend to train. That way you will see the gym and meet the trainers.




Then you can decide if we are the right gym for you.

It will be our pleasure to have you train at Gleason’s Gym during your time in New York




We are open seven days a week.






  • Monday through Friday, from 5:00 am until 10:00 pm.



  • On Saturday and Sunday from 8:00 am until 6:00 pm.



  • The daily gym fee is $25.







We have 92 trainers and their fee starts at $50 per hour. There is always someone available.




Come and have a good time. Do not forget to bring a camera.

Anthropomorphism is a formal writing mistake in which writers attribute human characteristics to non-human entities. Avoiding anthropomorphism reduces the ambiguity of writing. Are theories, studies, results, and other aspects of research capable of action?





Typical examples of anthropomorphism are as follows:




  • The research concluded…


  • The study described…


  • The investigation demonstrates…







Rephrase these statements as such:




  • The researchers concluded…


  • The results suggest …


  • The investigators demonstrated…


  • The data provide evidence that…







For more information on this topic, please see:




  • The APA Publication Manual, Seventh Edition covers anthropomorphism in Section 4.11 (Page 117).
  • https://apastyle.apa.org/style-grammar-guidelines/grammar/anthropomorphism

  3. Providing the community with access to clinical research data (via the iTHRIV Commons, coming soon!)
  4. Providing opportunities for shared problem-solving
  5. Funding for addressing community problems and questions


Whether you’re a patient or someone concerned about health in your community, you can help improve current treatments or discover new ones.

There is no shortage of fabulous things to do and places to see in the Cotswolds. Here are few ideas to get you started:




  • Antique Shopping/Browsing
  • Batsford Arboretum and Garden Centre
  • Blenheim Palace
  • Chastleton House and Garden
  • Cheltenham Festival
  • Cotswold Falconry
  • Daylesford Farm
  • Hiking in the Cotswolds
  • Lemington Lakes
  • Longborough Festival Opera
  • Mill Dene Garden
  • Sezincote House and Garden
  • Wellington Aviation Museum



For more information check out Cotswold Life.





Finally, previous guests may have left useful tips and hints in the ‘Holiday Hints’ book. If you have a great day out during your stay, please provide information in the holiday hints book for the benefit of future guests.

Sites internet incontournables:





Que ce soit pour les élèves ou leurs parents, plusieurs sites s’avèrent un support important pour guider et soutenir l’accompagnement à chacune des étapes du cheminement scolaire et professionnels. En voici quelques-uns :




  • Espace parent: pour accompagner son enfant à travers son cheminement scolaire et professionnel


  • Repères : banque d’informations scolaires et professionnelles (disponible à partir du courriel de la CSBF de l’élève)
  • Mon emploi.com: exploration de formations et de métiers
  • Inforoute : Formation professionnelle et technique (toute la province)
  • Admission en formation professionnelle (SRAFP)
  • Admission au collégial (regroupements des CÉGEPS, collèges publics et collèges privés):

    • Montréal (SRAM)
    • Québec (SRACQ)
    • Saguenay / Lac Saint-Jean (SRALS)
    • Association des collèges privés du Québec


  • Aide financière aux études
  • Les forces canadiennes
  • Pour les centres de formation professionnelle, CÉGEP ou collèges et universités : voir le site de chaque établissement d’enseignement.







Recherche d’emploi:





Les Carrefours jeunesse-emploi disposent de nombreux services spécialisés en matière de recherche d’emploi et autres pour les 16 – 35 ans. Voici les principaux que se trouvant dans la région :




  • Carrefour Jeunesse Emploi Arthabaska
  • Carrefour Jeunesse Emploi Comté Richmond-Drummondville-Bois-Francs





Séjours linguistiques et interculturels :





Plusieurs organismes ont pour mission de permettre l’apprentissage d’une autre langue et la découverte d’autres cultures. En voici quelques-uns :





Pour étudier quelques mois ou une année soit dans une autre province canadienne ou dans un autre pays :




  • EF Canada (Education First)
  • ASSE (International Student Exchange Programs)
  • AFS Interculturel (Intercultural programs)





Pour apprendre l’anglais au Québec ou séjourner dans une autre province canadienne :




  • Séjours linguistiques VTE
  • Programme EXPLORE
  • Emploi d’été – échanges étudiants YMCA
  • Programme VIT (ouest canadien)

Ingresa en el link "TIENDA" de nuestro menú principal.




  1. En la página principal de la tienda encontrarás nuestros artículos destacados. Si deseas buscar otros artículos, selecciona buscar por: Categorías o Tipo.


  2. Selecciona el producto de tu preferencia con un clic. Acorde al producto que desees, se te pedirá elegir el modelo o la talla. Si deseas más de 1 unidad, cambia la cantidad.


  3. Lee la descripción del producto si deseas conocer sus características, stock disponible por modelo y notas importantes.


  4. Da clic en añadir a la cesta. Cada artículo que selecciones irá al "Carrito de compras".


  5. Si deseas comprar más artículos, navega dando clic en los vínculos ubicados bajo el titular de la página abierta o repite los pasos anteriores hasta que hayas elegido todos los artículos que deseas adquirir.


  6. Cuando tengas todo lo que deseas en el carrito de compras, da clic en el ícono del carrito para ver tu selección. Si deseas editar los artículos que seleccionaste, revisa ¿Cómo editar los artículos de la cesta de compras?.


  7. Si estás satisfech@ con tu elección ingresa tu dirección de correo electrónico y selecciona lo siguiente:



    OBLIGATORIO: Marca el casillero (Estoy de acuerdo con los Términos y Condiciones)



    OPCIONAL: Manténgame informado de las novedades y ofertas exclusivas.


  8. Si tienes un código promocional, ingrésalo. Más información en: ¿Cómo usar un código promocional o cupón de descuento?


  9. Da clic en Pagar y realiza el proceso de pago. Más información en ¿Cómo pagar mi pedido?
  10. Nos contactaremos contigo para concretar la compra.


NOTA: Si requieres ayuda visual, en el video a continuación te presentamos un ejemplo de compra. Agrándalo para que puedas visualizarlo mejor:

• Bio: I'm a writer, filmmaker, and TTRPG creator/GM with experience in professional reading and editing. Currently I intern in the publishing and film business, where I read manuscripts with an eye especially for disability. I'm autistic and mentally ill, and passionate about advocating for disability representation in gaming. Some of my favorite things are sci-fi and anything weird! I work with the DnD Disability project as a writer and consultant, and we were recently awarded a Patreon Grant toward our project. I offer sensitivity reading, specifically for autism and sensory disorders, as well as mental health and queer rep. I have professional experience reading and reviewing manuscripts or games and highlighting disability, and have experience with accessibility in gaming through my work with DnD Disability. I'm happy to read, edit, or consult on positive disability representation and mechanics in gaming, as well as review projects for accessibility!

    ​​​​​​​


  • Services offered: Consulting and Education, Sensitivity Reading, Writing and Game Design, Additional Services.

    ​​​​​​​


  • ​Preferred contact method: Email (theaimeemeester@gmail.com) or twitter DMs.

    ​​​​​​​


  • Previous projects / portfolios: DnD Disability (current): https://www.dnddisability.com/, most recently our upcoming autism mechanics for D&D5e.

    ​​​​​​​


  • Website and Social Media links: https://www.aimeemeester.com/, Twitter: @theaimeemeester

Chez Fleur de Pains, le partage et l’écoute sont deux points importants ! C’est pourquoi vous pouvez retrouver Fleur de Pains sur les réseaux sociaux suivants :




  • Facebook
  • Instagram
  • Linkedin



Les échanges avec la communauté Fleur de Pains sont enrichissants et nous permettent d’être à l’écoute de nos clients tout en les informant sur nos dernières nouvelles exclusives et en leur montrant l’envers du décor chez Fleur de Pains.
